glossary.item: When someone says something that others think is nice
A thing or an independent being—in this case, a political movement or ideology
Making exciting without regard for the truth
Irresponsible reporting in an attempt to get more readers
Spreading quickly without anyone checking it
A job where you will gain experience working for the industry for a set period of time, often unpaid
Introductory sentence in a news story
Be short, simple, and to the point
A difficult problem in which the answer is not immediately clear
Short, interesting stories about people, places, or events
An assertion of the truth of something, typically one that is disputed or in doubt
Secondary meanings; feelings that people attach to words
A mistaken belief founded on inaccuracies and unsound logic
The practice of making decisions as a group, which discourages creativity and avoids personal responsibility
Network providers must show no bias toward or priority for information passed over the network
On the spot, without much or any preparation
Phrases such as "President Obama said" or "According to the Secretary of State" that signal to your audience that you are quoting someone else
Person who tells the public or press about wrongdoings in his or her organization
Information that was interpreted by someone else
Scientists who study the atmosphere and often report the weather
